Award.AwardTitle: Faculty Tenure and Promotion Workshop Series

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is in our national interest to support the advancement of scientific progress, national health, and general prosperity in an economy increasingly driven by scientific advancement and technological change. Colleges and universities are engaged in an ongoing process of adapting to societal changes and emerging scholarship that inform the ways we provide effective STEM learning environments. Institutional policies relating to faculty promotion and tenure can serve as incentives for faculty members to participate in activities such as outreach and public engagement, use evidence-based teaching and mentoring practices, develop and offer creative interdisciplinary or transdisciplinary coursework, create novel ways to broaden participation in science among underrepresented groups, and develop specific strategies for reflecting the principles of convergence in courses and programs.

The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine will organize and host a national convocation of key scholars and stakeholders. The gathering is designed to incorporate speakers and participants that represent a wide range of STEM instructional faculty, including contingent faculty, at a range of higher education institutional types. The gathering will be planned by an ad hoc committee of the National Academies with experience and expertise in science and engineering, promotion and tenure policies and practices, and higher education research and teaching. The convocation will bring together 50-75 stakeholders to discuss the issues and research and to determine strategies for creating campus-based conversations aimed at examining new promotion and tenure policies and practices. The gathering is designed to serve as a springboard for a major National Academies consensus study of this topic starting in 2019.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes for the National Academies of Sciences Project:

Faculty Tenure and Promotion Workshop Series

 

Faculty in science, technology, engineering, and medicine (STEM) are expected to excel in their technical work, teaching, and professional service. However, there is a growing concern that the evaluation of those accomplishments and traditional incentive systems are misaligned with some of the values and missions of higher education institutions, such as student learning, public engagement, and innovative research. In response to this concern, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine convened academic leaders, scientists, engineers, medical professionals, scholars, philanthropists, and representatives from higher education associations and research funding agencies at a two-day workshop in October 2019 to discuss challenges with the current system of faculty advancement and to re-envision promotion practices. Sessions spanned several topics related to faculty promotion and advancement: the historical context and current realities of academic advancement, evaluation and assessment models for academic careers, new models for faculty advancement, and potential changes to existing advancement systems. Particular emphasis was placed on aligning faculty reward pathways to institutional and departmental missions and values.


Intellectual merit


Throughout the course of the workshop, panelist and workshop participants contributed to the intellectual merit of the on-going national dialog on faculty promotion and advancement. After an overview of perspectives from the sponsors as well as the President of the the National Academy of Sciences on key themes that have been and should continue to be central foci in these discussions, a panel of experts representing different areas of academic science, engineering, and medicine established a common baseline of understanding of the benefits and limitations of the current systems of reward and advancement. 


Other sessions during the workshop identified institutions of higher education—and programs and departments within institutions—that are experimenting with new models of promotion and tenure, such as the non-traditional advancement system of Olin College of Engineering and the student-focused system of the Department of Chemistry at University of Michigan. Speakers discussed both challenges and promising models of systemic change initiatives such as Project Kaleidoscope and the NSF ADVANCE program, and explored qualitative and quantitative approaches that can be used in faculty assessment, such as research and scholarship, teaching, professional service, mentoring, and outreach and community engagement.


During the final workshop sessions, the participants envisioned the next steps that need to be taken by identifying key actors and levers of change, and prioritizing both immediate and longer-term actions to support comprehensive reforms of promotion and advancement policies;


Broader Impacts 


Both the workshop and the published proceedings in brief resulted in numerous broader impacts relating to faculty advancement. At the in-person workshop, a diverse group of participants engaged in the facilitated conversations, expanding the reach of the workshop messaging and themes. The participants represented a range of institutions, including two and four-year higher education institutions, higher education associations, philanthropic organizations, scientific and professional societies, and think-tanks. In addition, participants also represented different career tracks and stages, including graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, non-tenure track faculty, tenure and tenure-track faculty, Congressional staff, university administrators, and higher education researchers. 


Following the October workshop, the committee chair and a committee member relayed the workshop themes and discussions at a session for the 2020 Annual Meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS). The room for that session was at full capacity and attendees expressed a desired interest in continued work on faculty advancement in STEM fields. Of note from the AAAS session were comments that university librarians should be considered in future faculty advancement efforts since many librarians hold tenured faculty positions and participate in research and education efforts. 


The conversations from this workshop will inform two upcoming National Academies consensus studies: one study is on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on higher education and the other will focus on the impact of the pandemic specifically on the research careers of academic women. Both consensus studies will likely examine how the pandemic has impacted faculty hiring, employment status, and advancement.
